Using zip files

Ian Lyttle

2017-04-23

library("ieeecomtrade")
library("dplyr")
## 
## Attaching package: 'dplyr'
## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
## 
##     filter, lag
## The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
## 
##     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library("readr")
library("stringr")

Let’s read a zip file into a raw vector.

file <- ct_example("keating_1999.zip")

raw <- readBin(file, "raw", n = file.size(file))

Next, let’s see if we can tell what is inside the zip file:

unzip(file, list = TRUE) %>%
  filter(!str_detect(Name, "^__MAC"))
##                   Name Length                Date
## 1 victoria_keating.CFG    976 2017-04-07 13:41:00
## 2 victoria_keating.DAT  98616 2017-04-07 13:41:00
cfg <- read_file(unz(file, "victoria_keating.CFG"))
dat <- read_file(unz(file, "victoria_keating.DAT"))

config <- ct_read_config(cfg)
dat <- ct_read_data_config(dat, config)

ct <- comtrade(config, dat)

ct_instant(ct, channel_name = ct_channel_name(ct, "ph"))
## # A tibble: 2,048 × 9
##         instant         I1       I2        I3           I4        V1
##           <dbl>      <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl>        <dbl>     <dbl>
## 1  0.000000e+00  -5.671533 175.6419 -177.0687 1.100606e+00 -208.3977
## 2  3.256561e-05  -7.252448 175.8001 -174.1653 8.254547e-01 -215.3405
## 3  6.513121e-05  -9.742390 174.7522 -171.7754 1.705303e-13 -221.8280
## 4  9.769682e-05 -12.014955 174.7918 -169.2670 1.375758e+00 -226.4944
## 5  1.302624e-04 -14.247998 174.6336 -167.0154 1.650909e+00 -230.1366
## 6  1.628280e-04 -16.322949 174.3766 -165.6525 5.503031e-01 -235.4859
## 7  1.953936e-04 -18.516469 174.2580 -163.7169 5.503031e-01 -241.6320
## 8  2.279592e-04 -21.085456 174.4161 -161.3468 2.751516e-01 -248.5748
## 9  2.605248e-04 -22.903508 173.9021 -159.8062 1.705303e-13 -254.1518
## 10 2.930904e-04 -24.780845 174.0405 -158.6014 1.375758e+00 -258.1354
## # ... with 2,038 more rows, and 3 more variables: V2 <dbl>, V3 <dbl>,
## #   V4 <dbl>

So far, so good.

What we want is a function that will take a zip file and return a comtrade object. Which is kinda what we have above.

In future, we will want to be able to deal with the zip file without having to access the file system - so in future, our function would take a raw vector representing a zip file and return a comtrade object. This may make things easier as we use a REST API client to access the zip file.

Developed by Ian Lyttle, Schneider Electric.
